oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sketch of Fort Delaware
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil sketch of one side of this prison for Confederate soldiers drawn by Dr. William Mark Eames, Federal surgeon. On the back of the image appears the notation, "Picture of Fort Deleware Del which Dr drew while there in 1864 guarding rebel prisoners."

Fort Delaware served as a harbor defense facility for the Delaware River beginning with the War of 1812. The pentagon-shaped fortification present during the Civil War had been constructed from 1848-1859 and was the largest fort in the country. Confederate prisoners and local Southern sympathizers were housed in wooden barracks on Pea Patch Island, not inside the fort itself. Most prisoners were captured at Gettysburg. The prison held forty thousand men by war's end; approximately 2,700 died there.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Eames, Dr. William Mark
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Fort Delaware (Del.); United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 --Prisoners and prisons
